Pneumonia etiopathogenesis, Pulmonary defences against infection, Pathology, Understanding common symptoms and signs in Pneumonia, Classification, Characteristics of common pneumonia --- Pneumonia --- # PNEUMONIA Acute respiratory illness [Fever | SOB | Cough | Chest pain] & radiological Pulmonary Shadowing > Most research on nosocomial pneumonia has focused on VAP ## Types of Pneumonia | COMMUNITY ACQUIRED / CAP | HOSPITAL ACQUIRED / HAP | VENTILATOR ASSOCIATED / VAP | | :----------------------- | :---------------------- | :-------------------------- | | - Occurs in community | * Occurs after 48 hrs in hospitalised pts | - Occurs after 48-72hrs of IMV | | * MCC CAP => Strept. Pneumoniae | **MCC HAP =>** | **Early VAP** | | * MCC CAP => Hospitalisation | - gram-ve bacilli > | < 5 days | | * MCC CAP => ICU admission | - staph aureus | - Strept. Pneumonia | | | | - H. influenzae | | | | **Late VAP** | | | | > 5 days | | | | - Pseudomonas | | | | - Staph. aureus | | | | - Acinetobacter | *Note: Hospital Acquired Pneumonia (HAP) and Ventilator Associated Pneumonia (VAP) are types of Nosocomial Pneumonia.* --- # Clinical classification | TYPICAL PNEUMONIA | ATYPICAL PNEUMONIA | |---|---| | * Fever + productive cough | * Fever + dry cough [scanty sputum] | | * Predominant Neutrophilic Leukocytosis | * mild leukocytosis | | * Sputum gram stain reveals organism | * Gram stain reveals no organisms | | * CXR: Alveolar exudates | * CXR: Uncommon Alveolar exudates
* Interstitial pattern | | * MCC => Strep. pneumonia, H. influenza, Staph, Klebsiella, Pseudomonas. | MCC Atypical pneumonia: Mycoplasma, Legionella, Chlamydia, Viral pneumonia
MCC Atypical pneumonia => ICU admission
=> Legionella, viral | --- # Pathogenesis Microorganisms may reach the lungs via the airways (Aspiration / Inhalation), bloodstream, or lymphatics or Direct spread First step in many infections is colonization of the upper airway and reach lung by micro aspiration from the oropharynx. --- A plethora of microorganisms, including viruses, bacteria, and fungi, are inhaled daily, mainly in dust or aerosol particles. WHY EVERY ONE IS NOT DEVELOPING PNEUMONIA ??? --- Pulmonary defence mechanism OPD → Alveolar ↓ Alveolar ↓ mucociliary esc... --- * **Muco-ciliary blanket**: Microorganisms in large particles are trapped $\rightarrow$ transported to the back of the throat, where they are swallowed and cleared. * Respiratory epithelial cells: $\rightarrow$ defensins and cathelicidins have antimicrobial activity $\rightarrow$ prevent adherence and colonization by potential bacterial pathogens * LUNG INNATE & ACQUIRED IMMUNITY : either kill or infected ones are eliminated via either the mucociliary elevator or the lymphatics --- HOW WILL BODY FIGHT ?? : IMMUNE CELLS ASSEMBLE (Image: A scale with "Body's Defences" on the left pan and a finger pressing down on the right pan labeled "Pathogen load".) (Image: A dark image of a crowd of people, possibly in a confrontational setting.) Immune cells initiate the inflammatory response that triggers the clinical syndrome of pneumonia. --- # Immunity ## Innate * [Acute inflammation] * Inherent, non specific * Immediate & first line * Components 1. Neutrophils * 2. Macrophages * * => Bacterial infection 3. Dendritic cells NMD ## Acquired * [Chronic] * Adapts to infectious agent * & generates specific mechanism to neutralise them * T cells, B cells NK cells Natural Killer cells (⊗ clearance of pathogen) by lung --- # Immunity → Acute inflammation ## Vascular events * ↑ Vascular permeability [most Characteristic] * \* Leakage of fluid & proteins into tissue to facilitate mediator reach to tissue * Mediators: PGs & Histamine, Bradykinins (PAF) * Vasodilation => ↑ Vascular Permeability ## Cellular events * IL8 ↑ in response to inflammation (By damaged cells, MΦs, DC etc) * \*\* Immune cells from blood reach to tissue * Binding of Neutrophils to endothelium mediated by Selectins & Integrins * - (Diapedesis) [move into tissue] & get activated * By Neutrophils & MΦs * ↑ IL1 ↑ TNFα ## Phagocytosis (Diagram showing cells moving from a blood vessel into tissue) * Blood vessel * Neutrophils --- * most important defence => Phagocytosis by innate immunity I. Recognition of Infection by TLR, NLR, RLR, CLR - Toll Like Receptor - Nodd " - Rig " - C-lechn " Identified by molecular Pattern - PAMP - Pathogen Associated Molecular Patterns - DAMP - Damage Associated Molecular Pattern *(Partial text from embedded image: Apoptotic cells and TLR ligands, PAMPs)* --- **Receptor Types:** - **TLR** (Toll Like Receptor) - **NLR** (Nodd Receptor) - **RLR** (Rig Receptor) - **CLR** (C-Lechn Receptor) These receptors are **Identified by molecular Pattern**. | PAMP | DAMP | | :--------------------------------- | :--------------------------------- | | Pathogen Associated Molecular Patterns | Damage Associated Molecular Pattern | | [Bacteria => LPS] | [Necrotic cell] | **Diagram Elements:** - Apoptotic cells and TLR ligands - DC (Dendritic Cell) - PAMPs - Apoptotic cell bodies - MHC I - Immunological outcome? --- ## II Pathogen engulfment => Phagosome formation * Infection by S. aureus * Neutrophil activation * Phagocytosis * Engulfment ## III Pathogen killing * Phagolysosome formation * Enzymatic killing * Reactive Oxygen Species (ROS) * Oxygen independent (e.g., cell-derived defensins) --- ### III Pathogen killing * **Phagolysosome formation** * (Diagram: A cell engulfs a pathogen, forming a phagosome. A lysosome (labeled 'L') fuses with the phagosome to form a phagolysosome.) * This process leads to: * **Enzymatic killing** * *Mechanisms:* * **Reactive Oxygen species (ROS)** * [effective killing] * **Oxygen independent** * - cathepsin, Defensin * Cathsedins Dr. Bharath kathi MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM --- Why Pneumonia happens in few ??? **HOST FACTORS** * ↓↓ local defense mechanisms * ↓↓ the systemic resistance of the host is lowered. **PATHOGEN FACTORS** * ↑ virulence of organism * ↑ infectious load --- # ↑ Pneumonia ## LOCAL DEFENCE * ↓↓ cough reflex * Disfaction of the **mucociliary** apparatus → **cigarette smoke** / viral diseases / immotile cilia syndromes * Accumulation of secretions : cystic fibrosis and bronchial obstruction. * ↓ phagocytic activity of **alveolar** macrophages by alcohol / **tobacco smoke** * Pulmonary congestion ## ↓↓ THE SYSTEMIC RESISTANCE * chronic diseases : **DM**, **CKD**, **CLD** * Immunologic deficiencies : **HIV**, common variable immunodeficiency (CVID), **X-linked agammaglobulinemia** (inherited), * treatment with **immunosuppressive agents**, and **leukopenia**. * ↓ organ transplant --- * Disfunctio of the mucociliary apparatus ➔ cigarette smoke / viral diseases / immotile cilia syndromes * Accumulation of secretions : cystic fibrosis and bronchial obstruction. * ↓ phagocytic activity of alveolar macrophages by alcohol /tobacco smoke * Pulmonary congestion and edema * Immunologic deficiencies : HIV, common variable immunodeficiency (CVID), X-linked agammaglobulinemia (inherited), treatment with immunosuppressive agents, and leukopenia. * ↓ steroid/ organ transplant --- # FEW SPECIAL EXAMPLES OF Pathogen factors * **Streptococcus pneumoniae**: contains multiple adhesions, binds to the receptor for platelet-activating factor on epithelial cells, enhanced by cigarette smoke * **Staphylococcus aureus**: multiple adhesins that bind host extracellular matrix proteins * **Influenza viruses**: hemagglutinins that bind to sialic acid on the surface of epithelial cells. * **SARS CoV2**: binds to ACE2 receptor of nasal and alveolar epithelial cells. * **Mycoplasma pneumoniae**: release toxins to impair ciliary activity. * **Mycobacterium tuberculosis**: survives within the phagocyte. --- **Handwritten Notes:** * Streptococcus → PMP * Staph → EMP * Influenza → HA → Sialic acid * SARS CoV2 → ACE2 * 2. Mtb resist Killing by phagocyte **Diagram Labels:** * MAB * Spike protein * ACE2 --- * Staphylococcus aureus: multiple adhesins that bind host _extracellular matrix proteins_ * Influenza viruses: **hemagglutinins** that bind to _sialic acid_ on the surface of _epithelial cells_. * SARS CoV2: binds to **ACE2 receptor** of nasal and alveolar epithelial cells. * **Mycoplasma pneumoniae**: release **toxins** to impair **ciliary activity**. * **Mycobacterium tuberculosis**: survives within the *phagolysosomes of macrophages*. * (Handwritten note): { Mtb resist killing by phagocyte **Diagram Text:** * (Handwritten): MAB * (Handwritten): Spike protein * (Handwritten): ACE2 * (Printed): ACE2 --- # PATHOLOGICAL TYPES

## Lobar pneumonia
*   Diffuse consolidation involving the entire lobe of the lung
*   Four stages of lobar pneumonia have been described
*   MC pattern in CAP

## Bronchopneumonia
*   Patchy neutrophilic inflammation is centered in bronchi and bronchioles, with centrifugal spread to the adjacent alveoli may be due to aspiration of oropharyngeal contents.
*   MC Noscomial pneumonia pattern

## Interstitial pneumonia
*   Inflammation involving the interstitium is characterized by infiltration of lymphocytes and macrophages.
*   The alveoli do not contain a significant exudate.
*   Ex Viral pneumonia

---

# Lobar pneumonia

Diffuse consolidation involving the entire lobe of the lung
\* Four stages of lobar pneumonia have been described
MC pattern in CAP
ex: Streptococcus pneumonia

# Bronchopneumonia

Patchy neutrophilic inflammation in is centered in bronchi and bronchioles, with centrifugal spread to the adjacent alveoli may be due to aspiration of oropharyngeal contents.
MC Noscomial pneumonia pattern
Ex: Staph pneumonia

# Interstitial pneumonia

Inflammation involving the interstitium is characterized by infiltration of lymphocytes and macrophages.
The alveoli do not contain a significant exudate.
Ex Viral pneumonia
Atypical pneumonia

Multiple Cavitary Pneumonia

CA MRSA
Underlying pulmonary disease (e.g., COPD,
carcinoma, cystic fibrosis), chronic illness (e.g., diabetes
mellitus, renal failure), consequence of intravenous drug use or
septic embolization from endocarditis or an infected vascular
site.

Daptomycin is ineffective for treatment of pneumonia,
because it binds to and is inactivated by pulmonary surfactant

# Imp Atypical Pneumonias



## LEGIONELLA
*   Spread through contaminated water
Special features:
1.  Associated diarrhea, hyponatremia, Confusion, altered LFIs
2.  Poor response to βlactam
3.  Gram stain reveals no organism
4.  Occurs in old & Immunosuppressed
5.  Occurrence of illness $\bar{c}$ in 10 days discharge from hospital
Dx: Urine antigen Test, Serology, PCR [Polymerase chain Reaction]



## MYCOPLASMA
*   mc Atypical pneumonia
*   Walking pneumonia | Eaton agent pneumonia
*   Extra pulmonary features:
    1.  Skin: Rash, Erythemanodosum, Steven Johnson Synd
    2.  Joints: Arthritis
    3.  Cvs: Pericarditis, myocarditis
    4.  Blood: $\uparrow$ Cold agglutinins $\Rightarrow$ Hemolytic Anemia
    5.  CNS: Encephalitis, GBS, No cell wall
Dx: Serology, PCR



## Rx (Treatment)
General options: Fluoroquinolone, Macrolide, or Tetracycline
*   **For Legionella:** Fluoroquinolone (e.g., Levo, MoxiKox) or Macrolide
*   **For Mycoplasma:** Macrolide (e.g., Azithro) or Tetracycline

# Chlamydia

*   C. pneumoniae (formerly Chlamydia pneumoniae) accounts for 5% to 15% of cases of CAP
*   asymptomatic: an acute, mild respiratory tract infection is observed in only 10% of infected adolescents and young adults.
*   Sore throat with hoarseness is often severe and may precede pneumonia by up to a week and resolve before pneumonia onset, resulting in a biphasic illness.
*   C. pneumoniae cannot be visualized by Gram stain, and tissue culture is required to grow the pathogen.
*   Although direct fluorescent antibody detection of C. pneumoniae is available, PCR if available

Rx: Tetracycline | Doxycycline CTD

## OTHER PNEUMONIA SYNDROMES



### Aspiration Pneumonia
*   Anaerobic oral flora (Bacteroides, Prevotella, Fusobacterium, Peptostreptococcus).



### Chronic Pneumonia
*   Nocardia, Actinomyces
*   Mycobacterium tuberculosis
*   Histoplasma capsulatum
*   NTM



### Pneumonia in the Immunocompromised
*   Cytomegalovirus
*   Pneumocystis jiroveci
*   Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare complex
*   Invasive aspergillosis
*   Invasive candidiasis



### Necrotizing Pneumonia and Lung Abscess
*   Anaerobic bacteria
*   Staph aureus
*   Klebsiella pneumoniae
*   Pseudomonas

## Sputum gram stain & culture:
* Severe CAP
* Patients receiving empiric treatment for *Pseudomonas aeruginosa* or MRSA
* Patients with prior infection with *P. aeruginosa* or MRSA
* Patients who have been hospitalized and received parenteral antibiotics (whether during the hospitalization or not) in the last 90 days



## Blood Cultures



## High quality sputum:
* (>25 Neutrophils)
* sputum sample is free from upper airway contamination is critical.
* In general, fewer than 10 squamous epithelial cells per low power field
* Sputum 2 ml in quantity & mucopurulent

Legionella and pneumococcal urinary antigen testing
* ? Legionella outbreak or travel
* Severe CAP

Testing respiratory sample for influenza virus
* When influenza is circulating in community (use of a rapid influenza molecular assay is recommended)

RAPID PCR
A growing number of multiplex platforms now identify bacteria and genes associated with antibiotic resistance. Useful in intubated patients with severe CAP where the rapid testing of lower respiratory tract specimens may aid the timely identification and treatment of drug-resistant pathogens.
More evidence needed

Diagnostic bronchoscopy with BAL with or without biopsy may be useful in non-resolving CAP.
Protected specimen brush is more specific for diagnosing causative organisms

# Assessment of severity of Pneumonia

The CRB65 score is used to assess the severity of pneumonia. One point is awarded for each of the following criteria present:

*   ① **C**onfusion
*   ② **U**rea > 40mg/dL (or) > 7mmol/L
    *   *(BUN: 20mg%.)*
*   ③ **R**espiratory rate > 30/min
*   ④ **B**lood pressure: SBP < 90 (or) DBP < 60
*   ⑤ **65**: Age > 65 years

*(These criteria collectively form the CRB65 score)*

---

**Risk Stratification based on CRB65 Score:**

*   **0, 1 points:** Outpatient treatment (OPRx)
*   **2 points:** Ward treatment (WARD Rx)
*   **3, 4, 5 points:** Inpatient treatment (IPRx)

---

<!-- Page 50 -->

CRB 65

*   (U) $\rightarrow$ Urea > 40mg/dl (or) > 7mmol/L
*   (R) $\rightarrow$ resprate > 30/min
*   (B) $\rightarrow$ SBP < 90 (or) DBP < 60
*   (65) $\rightarrow$ Age > 65

0,1 $\Rightarrow$ OPRx
2 $\Rightarrow$ WARD Rx
3-5 $\Rightarrow$ Consider as severe pneumonia may require ICU
} IPRx

PSI

* Risk class II: score $\le 70$
* Risk class III: score of 71–90
* Risk class IV: score of 91–130
* Risk class V: score of >130

* Risk classes IV and V: IP Rx
* Risk class III: careful clinical judgement

# TABLE 128-5 Criteria for Severe Community-acquired Pneumonia



## Minor criteria$^a$
*   Respiratory rate $\ge 30$ breaths/min$^b$
*   PaO$_2$/FiO$_2 \le 250^b$
*   Multilobar infiltrates
*   Confusion/disorientation
*   Uremia (BUN $\ge 20$ mg/dL)
*   Leukopenia (WBC count $<100,000$ cells/mm$^3$)$^c$
*   Hypothermia (core temperature $<36^\circ$C)
*   Hypotension requiring aggressive fluid resuscitation



## Major criteria
*   Invasive mechanical ventilation
*   Septic shock with need for vasopressors

---

<!-- Page 56 -->



# Empirical regimens for CAP



## OPRx [oral]



### NO comorbidities
*   Macrolide (or)
*   βlactam (or)
*   Tetracycline



### With Comorbidities
*   (i) βlactam + macrolide (for common + typical organisms)
*   (or) (ii) Fluoroquinolone (for common + atypical organisms)



## IPRx [Inj/oral]



### Non ICU
*   (i) βlactam + macrolide
*   (or) (ii) FQ

### ICU
*   (i) βlactam + macrolide
*   (or) (ii) βlactam + FQ

---

\* In ICU
*   If Pseudomonas suspected: Antipseudomonal βlactam [Added]
*   If CAMRSA suspected $\Rightarrow$ Add Inj vancomycin | Inj Linezolid

---

Table 4. Doses of drugs used in community acquired pneumonia

| Drug                   | Doses                                                               |
| :--------------------- | :------------------------------------------------------------------ |
| Amoxicillin            | 0.5-1 g thrice daily (PO or IV)                                     |
| Co-amoxiclav           | 625 mg thrice a day to 1 g twice daily (PO) / 1.2 g thrice daily (IV) |
| Azithromycin           | 500 mg daily (PO or IV)                                             |
| Ceftriaxone            | 1-2 g twice daily (IV)                                              |
| Cefotaxime             | 1 g thrice daily (IV)                                               |
| Cefepime               | 1-2 g two to three times a day (IV)                                 |
| Ceftazidime            | 2 g thrice daily (IV)                                               |
| Piperacillin-tazobactam| 4.5 g four times a day (IV)                                         |
| Imipenem               | 0.5-1 g three to four times a day (IV)                              |
| Meropenem              | 1 g thrice daily (IV)                                               |

XFQ X
PO=Per orally; IV=Intravenous

---

<!-- Page 59 -->

# DISCHARGE

If Pt start accepting orally, are afebrile and are haemodynamically stable for a period of at least 48 hours.

Out-patients should be treated for five days and in-patients for seven days

OP Rx: 5d
IP Rx: 7d

---

<!-- Page 60 -->



## FOLLOW UP

*   Antibiotic may be changed if the response is not satisfactory even after 48 to 72 hours of treatment initiation
*   Radiological clearance is delayed compared to clinical resolution. Routine follow up chest x ray is not required if there is satisfactory clinical response
*   In case of smokers above 40 years or if there are any unusual features or if there is slow resolution, then it is better to get follow up chest x ray after 6 weeks or later
*   Hospitalized Patients may be followed up 1 week after discharge. A further follow up later is required in most of the patients to assess for complete resolution of pneumonia

---

<!-- Page 61 -->

ERS/ESICM/ESCMID/ALAT guidelines for the management of severe community-acquired pneumonia : 2023

only for


# Severe CAP / sCAP

*   If available, we suggest sending a lower respiratory tract sample (either sputum or endotracheal aspirates) for multiplex PCR testing (virus and/or bacterial detection) whenever non-standard sCAP antibiotics are prescribed or considered
*   sCAP + acute hypoxaemic respiratory failure not needing immediate intubation → high-flow nasal oxygen (HFNO) > standard oxygen
*   Addition of macrolides, not fluoroquinolones, to beta-lactams as empirical antibiotic therapy in hospitalised patients with sCAP

---

<!-- Page 62 -->

ROLE OF PROCALCITONIN IN sCAP

We suggest the use of PCT to reduce the duration of antibiotic treatment in patients with sCAP. The recommendation of using PCT must be considered together with clinical assessment. PCT might not be useful when clinical stability is achieved, and duration of antibiotic therapy is between 5 and 7 days

Procalcitonin is produced by the neuroendocrine cells of the lung and intestine released as an acute-phase reactant in response to inflammatory stimuli, especially those of bacterial origin (endotoxin and inflammatory cytokines).

↑ serum procalcitonin in response to viral infections and noninfectious inflammatory stimuli such as autoimmune disease and chronic inflammatory processes are much less pronounced, rarely exceeding 0.5 ng/ml.

---

<!-- Page 63 -->



# Biomarkers in pneumone

*   **Procalcitonin (PCT)** (1)
    *   \* Diagnosis of _bacterial_ versus _nonbacterial_ infection
    *   \* Need for antibiotic therapy
    *   Prediction of severity of CAP (ICU admission/ triaging emergency room patients)
    *   Prognosis of pneumonia patients
    *   \* Duration of antibiotic treatment
*   **C-reactive protein (CRP)** (2) ✓
    *   Prediction of severity of CAP ✓
    *   Diagnosis of bacterial versus nonbacterial infection
*   **Pro-adrenomedullin (Pro-ADM)** (3)
    *   Severity of CAP
*   **B-natriuretic peptide (BNP)** (4)
    *   Severity of CAP
*   **Troponin I** ↑ (5)
    *   Degree of _hypoxemia_: severity of illness

---

*   Serum CRP is an acute phase protein synthesized exclusively in the liver. Its secretion is initiated 4 to 6 h after an insult (effect mediated by cytokines _namely interleukin-6_)
*   ✓ _Mid-regional proadrenomedullin (MR-proADM)_ is a new biomarker of _endothelial damage_ and its clinical use is increasing in _sepsis_ and _respiratory infections_ and recently in SARS-CoV-2 infection
*   proinflammatory cytokines might increase plasma BNP from ventricles. A high BNP level (≥ 200 pg/mL) at admission was a predictor of _CAP-related death_
*   In response to _infection_, soluble TREM-1 (sTREM-1) is either secreted or shed. _sTREM-1 levels can then be measured in body_

---

*   Diagnosis of bacterial versus nonbacterial infection

<!-- Page 65 -->

ERS/ESICM/ESCMID/ALAT guidelines for the management of severe community-acquired pneumonia : 2023

We suggest the use of oseltamivir for patients with sCAP due to influenza confirmed by PCR. When PCR is not available to confirm influenza, we suggest the use of empirical oseltamivir during the influenza season.

In patients with sCAP, we suggest the use of corticosteroids if shock is present. Based on common exclusion criteria from clinical trials, this recommendation does not apply to patients with viral sCAP (influenza, SARS, and MERS), uncontrolled diabetes and corticos- teroid treatment for other reasons.

When corticosteroid therapy is considered, methylprednisolone (0.5 mg·kg-1 every 12 h for 5 days) is a reasonable option.

### Table 1 Summary of research questions and recommendations

1.  In patients with sCAP should rapid microbiologic techniques be added to current testing of blood and respiratory tract samples?
    *   VERY LOW
    *   If the technology is available, we suggest sending a lower respiratory tract sample (either sputum or endotracheal aspirate) for multiplex virus and/or bacterial detection whenever non-standard sCAP antibiotics are prescribed or considered.
    *   VERY LOW

2.  In hypoxemic patients with sCAP, can either NIV or HFNO initially – rather than supplemental standard oxygen administration – avoid intubation and reduce mortality?
    *   VERY LOW
    *   In patients with sCAP and acute hypoxemic respiratory failure not needing immediate intubation, we suggest using HFNO instead of standard oxygen.
    *   LOW
    *   NIV might be an option in certain patients with persistent hypoxemic respiratory failure not needing immediate intubation, irrespective of HFNO.
    *   LOW

3.  When using initial empiric therapy for sCAP, should macrolides or fluoroquinolones be used as part of combination therapy to reduce mortality and adverse clinical outcomes?
    *   VERY LOW
    *   We suggest the addition of macrolides, not fluoroquinolones, to beta-lactam as empiric antibiotic therapy in hospitalized patients with sCAP.
    *   VERY LOW

4.  In patients with sCAP, can serum PCT be used to reduce the duration of antibiotic therapy and improve other outcomes in comparison to standard of care not guided by serial biomarker measurements?
    *   VERY LOW
    *   We suggest the use of PCT to reduce the duration of antibiotic therapy in patients with sCAP.
    *   LOW

5.  Should oseltamivir be added to standard therapy with sCAP and confirmed influenza?
    *   VERY LOW
    *   We suggest the use of oseltamivir for patients with sCAP due to influenza confirmed by PCR.
    *   VERY LOW
    *   When PCR is not available to confirm influenza, we suggest empiric oseltamivir during the influenza season.
    *   LOW

6.  Does the addition of steroids to antibiotic therapy in specific sCAP populations lead to better outcomes in comparison to when steroid therapy is not used?
    *   VERY LOW
    *   In patients with sCAP, we suggest the use of corticosteroids when shock is present.
    *   LOW

# VENTILATOR ASSOCIATED EVENTS /VAE

*   The **CDC** defined a VAE as a sustained increase in ventilator support following a period of **stable or decreasing ventilator support**.
*   The VAE definition also includes **subcategories**.



## VENTILATOR ASSOCIATED CONDITION (VAC)
*   Baseline period of stability or improvement ≥ 2 Days
*   PLUS
*   Increase ≥ 2 days in FIO2 ≥ 0.2 or PEEP ≥ 3 cm H2O



## INFECTION RELATED VENTILATOR ASSOCIATED COMPLICATION (IVAC)
*   VAC
*   PLUS
*   Suspicion of infection\* and new antibiotic starts\*



## POSSIBLE VAP
*   IVAC plus Purulent secretions **or** Positive culture



## PROBABLE VAP
*   IVAC plus Purulent secretions **&** Positive culture

# VENTILATOR ASSOCIATED PNEUMONIA

1.  **Aspiration & intubation procedure**
    *   *Diagram elements:* Microorganisms in the oropharyngeal cavity, Epiglottis.

2.  **Biofilm formation**: Biofilm forms inside and outside the ET Tube → bacterial reservoir → spill over of bacteria from the biofilm into the lungs.
    *   *Diagram elements:* ETT, Cuff (ETT), Biofilm inner and outer surfaces of ETT in the region of cuff, Biofilm parts migrating to lungs, Lungs.

3.  **Contaminated secretions & resp equipment**: Secretions pool above ET cuff and intermittently seep around folds in the cuff, particularly if the cuff is underinflated.
    *   *Diagram element related to this:* Accumulation of contaminated fluids.

# WHEN TO SUSPECT NOSOCOMIAL PNEUMONIA ?? [Simplest]

*   Any patient with **new or progressive radiographic opacities** and clinical signs or symptoms indicative of infection: **fever, leukocytosis or leukopenia, purulent sputum, or worsening oxygenation.**
*   These clinical findings are neither sensitive nor specific, and there is **no gold standard** for the diagnosis of HAP or VAP

---

<!-- Page 75 -->

Modified Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) criteria for diagnosis of HAP/VAP

*   Chest radiographic opacities (new, progressive or persistent infiltrate or cavitation)
    AND
*   At least two of the following:
    1.  Fever >38 °C or >100.4 °
    2.  Leukopaenia (<4000 WBC/µL) or leukocytosis (≥12000 WBC/µL)
    3.  Altered mental status with no other recognised cause in the elderly
    4.  New onset of purulent sputum, or increased respiratory secretions,
    5.  Worsening gas exchange
    6.  New onset or worsening cough, or dyspnoea, or tachypnoea
    7.  Rales or bronchial breath sounds

| CPIS PARAMETERS       | 0                               | 1                               | 2                                         |
| :-------------------- | :------------------------------ | :------------------------------ | :---------------------------------------- |

| Chest xray infiltrates | No infiltrates                  | Diffuse                         | Localised                                 |
| Temperature           | 36 – 38.4 C                     | 38.5 – 38.9                     | $\ge 39$ or $\le 36$                      |
| Leucocytes            | $\ge 4000$ and $\le 11,000$     | $<4,000$ or $>11,000$           | $<4000$ or $>11,000$ plus band forms $\ge 500$ |
| PaO2/ FiO2            | $\ge 240$ or ARDS               |                                 | $\le 240$ and no evidence of ARDS         |
| Microbiology          | Negative                        |                                 | Positive                                  |

A score of more than 6 at baseline is suggestive of pneumonia.

# VAP

\* ETA VS BAL VS PSB
  10^5   10^4   10^3

* The bacteriologic strategy uses quantitative cultures of the LRT via endotracheal aspirate, protected specimen brush, or bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL).
* The thresholds differ depending on the method of respiratory sampling and are as follows: ≥10^5 • colony-forming units (CFU)/mL for an endotracheal aspirate,
* ≥10^4 • CFU/mL for a BAL,
* and ≥10^3 • CFU/mL for a protected specimen brush.
* Results of these procedures guide decisions such as when to initiate or stop antibiotics and the drug(s) to be used against the offending agent.
* There are no definitive data to support the use of one sampling technique over another; however, cellular analysis of BAL fluid may provide an advantage, as a \*sample containing <50% neutrophils produced excellent negative predictive value in one study.

# RISK FACTORS FOR MDR PATHOGENS

*   Antibiotics in last 90 days
*   Been hospitalised for >/5 days prior current HAP/VAP or >2 days in previous 90 days
*   Critical illness : Septic shock , ARDS prior VAP
*   Chronic lung disease : COPD, BXIS
*   Dialysis prior VAP
*   Evidence of high local antibiotic resistance
    *   Multiresistant GNB, such as P. aeruginosa,
    *   Extended-spectrum $\beta$-lactamase producing (ESBL) Enterobacteriaceae (Escherichia coli – and Klebsiella pneumoniae
    *   carbapenemase-producing organisms,
    *   MRSA,



## TABLE 129-7 Risk Factors for MDR Pathogens

*   Intravenous antimicrobials in previous 90 days
*   Chronic lung disease including COPD, cystic fibrosis, pulmonary fibrosis, or bronchiectasis
*   Residence in high-risk environment including LTAC or skilled nursing facility
*   Tracheostomy
*   Septic shock at the time of VAP onset
*   ARDS prior to VAP onset
*   Immunosuppressive therapy
*   Hospitalization for >2 days in the previous 90 days
*   Indwelling vascular or urinary catheter
*   Home wound care
*   Current hospitalization for 5 d or greater
*   High rates of local antibiotic resistance
*   Acute renal replacement therapy prior to VAP onset

# PHASES

Due to nasal epithelial involvement & Anosmia\*
1.  **Early infection phase:** Virus binds to nasal epithelial cells starts replicating. Mild symptoms, anosmia.
    *   Microthrombi formation
    *   $\uparrow$ D-dimer
    *   Rx: Anticoagulation
    *   (Diagram: Virus binding to ACE2 receptor)
2.  **Pulmonary phase:**
    *   alveolar type II cells involved $\rightarrow$ epithelial & capillary endothelial damage $\rightarrow$ leukocyte recruitment $\rightarrow$ pulmonary damage, hypoxemia and progress to ARDS.
3.  **Severe hyperinflammatory phase:**
    *   In few, the host inflammatory response continues to amplify $\rightarrow$ cytokine storm & Multi organ damage. Major mediator: IL-6.

Lymphocytes are highly vulnerable to the virus $\rightarrow$ lymphopenia

(Diagram: T-cells + Covid $\rightarrow$ Infected cell $\rightarrow$ Cytokine Storm IL6)

# COVID 19 National guidelines
\*Based on clinical criteria



## MILD
*NO oral steroids*
*   URT symptoms ± fever
    *   Home Isolation / Covid care centre
    *   Symptomatic care
    *   ~~Tab ivermectin / HCQ~~ (No definite evidence)
    *   Inhaled Budesonide if persistent fever/cough > 5 days of disease onset
    *   High risk pts
        *   Age > 60
        *   Comorbidities



## MODERATE
*   SpO2 ≤ 93% or RR ≥ 24/min
    *   WARD / Covid health care centre
    *   O2 SUPPORT. Target SpO2: 92-96% (88-92% in COPD)
    *   Proning
    *   Steroid
    *   Anticoagulation ↓ viral replication
    *   May Consider Remdesivir [Antiviral]

*Handwritten notes for Moderate:*
*   Inj. Methylpred 0.5 to 1 mg/kg (or an equivalent dose of dexamethasone): 5 to 10 days.
*   Anticoagulation: UFH or LMWH (Enoxaparin 0.5mg/kg per day SC OD).



## SEVERE
*   SpO2 < 90% or RR > 30/min
    *   Admit in ICU
    *   High flow Nasal Oxygen (HFNO) or NIV
    *   Steroids \*
    *   Anticoagulation \*
    *   Remdesivir, Anti IL6
    *   If not improving → Invasive mech ventilation & Ventilate as per ARDS Protocol

*Handwritten notes for Severe:*
*   Severe: 1-2mg/kg
*   Severe: 0.5mg/kg BP

<!-- Page 118 -->

EUA/Off label use (based on limited available evidence and only in specific circumstances):

*   **Remdesivir (EUA)** may be considered **ONLY** in patients with
    *   Moderate to severe disease (requiring **SUPPLEMENTAL OXYGEN**), **AND**
    *   **No renal or hepatic dysfunction** (eGFR <30 ml/min/m2; AST/ALT >5 times ULN (Not an absolute contradiction)), **AND**
    *   Who are **within 10 days of onset of symptom/s.**
    *   **Recommended dose: 200 mg IV on day 1 f/b 100 mg IV OD for next 4 days.**
    *   **Not to be used in patients who are NOT on oxygen support or in home settings**

**Tocilizumab** (Off-label) may be considered when **ALL OF THE BELOW CRITERIA ARE MET** => 2 doses
*   Presence of severe disease (preferably within 24 to 48 hours of onset of severe disease/ICU admission).
*   Significantly raised inflammatory markers (CRP &/or IL-6).
*   Not improving despite use of steroids.
*   No active bacterial/fungal/tubercular infection.
*   **Recommended single dose: 4 to 6 mg/kg (400 mg in 60kg adult) in 100 ml NS over 1 hour.**

## LONG COVID

*   Long covid defined as "not recovering [for] several weeks or months following the start of symptoms that were suggestive of covid, whether you were tested or not."

# HOW COMMON IS IT ?

"Profound fatigue" was a common symptom in most people with long covid.

Around 10% of patients who have tested positive for SARS-CoV-2 virus remain unwell beyond three weeks, and a smaller proportion for months : UK COVID Symptom Study
Even mild COVID can develop

## LONG COVID OR POST COVID SYNDROME

Long term tissue damage + Unresolved inflammation



### Pulmonary
*   Dyspnea ✓
*   Cough *
*   Mechanism:
    *   Fibrosis *
    *   Pulmonary thrombus, cough hypersensitivity



### Cardiac
*   Chest pain
*   Palpitations ***
*   Tachycardia **
*   Mechanism: direct viral invasion, inflammation of the myocardium, pericardium and conduction system *



### Neurological
*   Cognitive impairment ✓
*   Fatigue ***, Headache
*   depression insomnia
*   Mechanism: direct viral infection, ongoing neuro inflammation, micro vascular thrombosis & neuro degeneration



### Gastro Intestinal
*   Irritable bowel syndrome and dyspepsia **
*   Mechanism: Alteration in gut microbiota

### Immunological / other
*   Fatigue ✓
*   Joint pain ✓
*   Myalgia ✓
*   Orthostatic intolerance
*   Mechanism: Autoimmunity can develop due to complex immune mechanisms
*   Autonomic dysfunction

# POST COVID FATIGUE

The decrease in physical and/or mental performance that results from changes in central, psychological, and/or peripheral factors due to the COVID-19 disease

MINIMISE ENERGY EXPENDITURE



## POST COVID FATIGUE

*   **Central factors**: neurotransmitter levels (e.g., dopamine and serotonin), intrinsic neuronal excitability, inflammation, demyelination (resulting in changes in axonal conduction velocity)
*   **Peripheral factors**: COVID-19 may directly impact skeletal muscle → pain, skeletal muscle weakness, and injury occurrence
*   **Psychological factors**: Stress, anxiety, depression, and fear

DR. BHARATHI MD FIP

<!-- Page 129 -->



# RESPIRATORY FOLLOW UP OF COVID 19 Pts \*

Cared for in ICU¹ or HDU² or ward care with severe pneumonia\*
*(Handwritten: High dependency unit)*

Assessment at 4 – 6 weeks after discharge.



## BLOOD TESTS :
Ordered selectively after a careful H/O and examination
*   CBC, CRP
*   Ferritin X (inflammation and continuing prothrombotic state),
*   Troponin and D-dimer.

Modified from : BTS Guidance on Respiratory Follow Up of Patients with a Clinico-Radiological Diagnosis of COVID-19 Pneumonia v1.2 11/5/2020



## Post-COVID-19' holistic assessment :
*   Assessment and management of **breathlessness** & O2 requirements
*   Symptom or palliative or rehabilitatory care management where required
*   Assessment and management of anxiety
*   Consideration of a new diagnosis of venous thromboembolic disease (**VTE**)
*   CXR

OUR EXPERIENCE – Anti fibrotics OPD

When do I start?
☑️Resting hypoxemia beyond 2-3 weeks of covid illness with CT / CXR suggestive of fibrosis starting antifibrotics with pul rehabilitation

How do I monitor for response?
☑️every month with 6min walk test and clinical response.

When do I plan to stop Anti fibrotics?
☑️Once their resting spo2 improves will plan to stop antifibrotics. Any antifibrotic drugs take ❌ at least 1-3 months to demonstrate an effect. This was the time period at which the FVC started to improve compared to placebo in the INBUILD, INPULSIS, and ASCEND trials

☑️Nintedanib

☑️PT'S DETERMINATION AND PUL REHABILITATION

# STEROIDS

Ann Am Thorac Soc Vol 18, No 5, pp 773-779, May 2021
Internet address: www.atsjournals.org

837 patients who survived hospitalization for SARS-CoV-2 infection at a single center in the United Kingdom, the authors found that 7% of patients had persistent interstitial changes on chest computed tomography (CT) 6 weeks after hospital discharge. The majority of these (35 out of 59, or 4% of the entire cohort) had an organizing pneumonia (OP)-like pattern, with bilateral subpleural ground-glass infiltrates in a mid- to lower-zone distribution, at times associated with subpleural and peribronchial linear dense consolidation, and traction bronchiectasis in some patients. These patients were offered treatment with corticosteroids (0.5 mg/kg prednisolone) with a taper over 3 weeks, on average. All 30 patients who received corticosteroid treatment reported subjective improvement in breathlessness and physical functioning and had objective improvements in lung function and chest imaging.

...on moderately high uses of steroids through their illness [Figure 4].27 Steroids should, in our opinion, be continued on discharge if the CT scan prior to discharge continues to show significant GGOs and the patient remains hypoxic. At this stage again, we would caution against the use of large doses of oral steroids as they could worsen hyperglycemia and contribute to proximal myopathy which in turn would retard the patients' mobility and rehabilitation. We recommend using no more than 20-30 mg of prednisolone at discharge and tapering it on follow-up depending on the patient's response.

# Influenza

*   Single-stranded enveloped RNA viruses
*   Commonest cause of viral pneumonia in immunocompetent adults. It is transmitted via respiratory secretion



## Types

*   **Influenza A**
    *   (Influenza virus types A&B cause most human illness and the flu season)
    *   **Subtypes:**
        *   A(H1N1)
        *   A(H3N2)
*   **Influenza B**
    *   **Lineages:**
        *   B(Victoria)
        *   B(Yamagata)



## Surface Antigens

*   Surface antigens (Proteins) haemagglutinin and neuraminidase determine influenza serotype.
*   Genetic mutations may result in **antigenic shifts** (major genetic rearrangements between strains, associated with **pandemics** of influenza A—1918 (H1n1), 1957 (H2n2), & 2009 (H1n1))
*   **Antigenic drifts** (more minor genetic variations associated with epidemics) -H3N2 subtype of influenza A virus in india



## Functions of Viral Proteins

*   Haemagglutinin helps the virus invade a target cell.
*   Neuraminidase helps new virus particles break out of that cell.

---

<!-- Page 145 -->

H₁N₁: Swine flu
H₅N₁: Avian flu

*   Genetic rearrangement of virus occurs in **animal** and **bird reservoirs**, and the virus may then be transferred to humans, e.g. **2009 H1n1** was caused by **reassortment of strains**: **swine**, **human**, and **avian**
*   highly pathogenic **H5n1** avian [Bird flu]
    *   *no human-human transmission*



## INFLUENZA

*   Animal Influenza
*   Swine Flu
*   Human Influenza
*   Seasonal/ Pandemic Influenza

Ministry of Health & Family Welfare : Seasonal Influenza

**Cat A**: Patients with mild fever plus cough / sore throat + bodyache, headache, diarrhoea and vomiting. No need Oseltamivir and H1N1 testing.

**Cat B (i)**: Category-A PLUS + high grade fever and severe sore throat, → home isolation and Oseltamivir;

**Cat B(ii)**: Category-A PLUS individuals having one or more of the high risk conditions shall be treated with Oseltamivir. No tests for H1N1 is required for Category-B (i) and (ii).

**Cat C**: of Category-A and B, + one or more of the following: Breathlessness, chest pain, drowsiness, fall in blood pressure, sputum mixed with blood, bluish discolouration of nails;
- Immediate hospitalization testing and treatment and send for testing.

# CYTOMEGALOVIRUS PNEUMONIA
Pneumonia in I/c ⊖
Inf:- SS EnRNA

*   Enveloped dsDNA virus
*   Pneumonia in the immunocompromised
*   Infection in transplant recipients results from either transmission from a CMV positive donor (via the organ or a blood transfusion) or reactivation of latent CMV in a seropositive recipient as a result of immunosuppression.
*   Infection occurs most frequently during the first 4 months following organ or bone marrow transplantation, corresponding to the period of maximal t-cell suppression.
*   Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) increases the risk of CMV infection

# CMV Pathogenesis

*   partly related to **viral replication** but is also thought to have an **immunopathologic basis**.
*   Two patterns of histopathology have been described : One is a **miliary pattern**, with multiple focal lesions showing **extensive cytomegaly** with **localized necrobiosis**, **alveolar hemorrhage**, **fibrin deposition**, and **neutrophilic response**.
*   other is of **interstitial character**, with **alveolar-cell hyperplasia**, **interstitial edema**, lymphoid infiltration, and diffusely distributed **cytomegalic cells**.

# Imaging

*   **CXR** typically bilateral $\checkmark$ diffuse interstitial infiltrate, although lobar consolidation and localized haziness also described
*   **CT Features** include localized or diffuse ground-glass and nodular shadowing that may progress to airspace consolidation
*   **Dx**: $\checkmark$ PCR in serum or BAL, $\checkmark$ histologic evidence of viral inclusions on biopsy
*   **Rx**: Reduce immunosuppression where possible.
    *   $\checkmark$ Ganciclovir 5 mg/kg IV bd for 2-4 weeks
    *   $\checkmark$ Anti-CMV hyperimmune globulin or prolonged oral valganciclovir in cases of severe or relapsed disease.
    *   $\checkmark$ Alternative Rx: Foscarnet 60mg/kg tds for 2-3 weeks
    *   $\checkmark$ Recently, letermovir has been introduced for prophylaxis;

# Adenovirus

*   non-enveloped dsDNA viruses
*   Most common symptoms are those of **self-limiting upper airways infection**, which frequently mimics group A **streptococcal infection**, particularly in childhood
*   Can cause pneumonia and ARDS in adults
*   Occasional complications—**myocarditis, hepatitis, nephritis**, **meningoencephalitis**, and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
    *   *(Handwritten annotation next to myocarditis, hepatitis, nephritis: Heart, liver, kidney)*
*   Disseminated disease may occur in the **immunocompromised**
*   Diagnosis is from nasopharyngeal fluid, sputum, or BAI fluid **viral culture, antigen testing** or **PCR**, or quantitative **PCR** on blood
*   Rx : supportive, but severe cases may be treated with **cidofovir** ± IV immunoglobulin.

# RSV

*   Single-stranded enveloped RNA virus; subtypes A and B. <mark>Subtype A</mark> (more severe disease) - *some like influenza*
*   Very common cause of <mark>bronchiolitis</mark> and <mark>pneumonia</mark> in children.
*   Role in <mark>adult respiratory disease</mark> is more <mark>significant</mark> than previously
*   Clinical features in adults are usually of <mark>URTI</mark> or <mark>tracheobronchitis</mark>, but this may progress to <mark>pneumonia</mark>, particularly in the setting of underlying cardiac or <mark>respiratory disease</mark>, malignancy, or <mark>immunosuppression</mark>;
*   <mark>outbreaks</mark> affecting adults in hospitals and nursing homes also occur.
*   <mark>Dx</mark>: nasopharyngeal secretions and BAI fluid are often diagnostic; detection of <mark>RSV antigen</mark> / <mark>PCR-based test</mark> / <mark>serology</mark>
*   <mark>Bacterial superinfection</mark> may be a frequent complication
*   <mark>Rx</mark>: supportive. <mark>Ribavirin</mark> and <mark>steroids</mark> in the treatment of <ins>severe disease</ins> in adults is unclear\* \*
*   Reports of successful outcomes in bone marrow transplant recipients following treatment with <mark>ribavirin</mark> and <mark>immunoglobulin</mark>.

# Varicella pneumonia

*   Caused by **varicella-zoster virus** (an enveloped **dsDNA virus**) (Handwritten: Like CMV)
*   Pneumonia occurs in a *small proportion* of adults with **chickenpox or shingles** but can be severe
*   Risk factors: **smoking**, increased number of **skin spots (>100)**, **pregnancy (third trimester)**, **steroid treatment** and **immunocompromise**
*   CF: **H/O** recent exposure to a contact infected with **chickenpox or shingles** with rash (erythematous macules progressing to papules and then vesicles) f/b **Cough and breathlessness**, **pleuritic pain** and **haemoptysis** may occur
*   CXR typically shows a *diffuse small nodular infiltrate*; *hilar lymphadenopathy* and *pleural effusions* may uncommonly occur. Nodules may subsequently *calcify and persist*
*   (Handwritten checkmark) Diagnosis: **H/O exposure**, presence of rash, and CXR features. Cytological examination of *smears from skin lesions, serology, or viral culture or PCR on BAI fluid* may **confirm** the diagnosis
*   (Handwritten checkmark) Rx: **aciclovir** 10-12.5mg/kg IV tds for **7-10 days**
*   (Handwritten checkmark) Consider **early administration** of **varicella zoster immune globulin** for **immunocompromised and pregnant patients**

# HANTA VIRUS SYNDROME
[ Pul. renal involvement ]

**(1) Virus contained in rodent feces**
**(2) Infected feces become airborne**
**(3) Inhalation of feces by human**

*   Caused by single-stranded enveloped RNA hantaviruses
*   **Zoonotic disease**
*   CF: vague **flu-like symptoms** or can involve **hemorrhagic fever** and **renal syndrome (HFRS)**.
*   GI symptoms such as vomiting and abdominal pain.
*   SOB $\rightarrow$ **respiratory failure** and ARDS.
*   Shock may occur and is associated with a poor prognosis

- CBC : neutrophilia thrombocytopenia, ↑LDH , renal impairment and mildly abnormal LFTs
- Leucocytosis and immunoblasts in peripheral blood are associated with severe disease
- CXR : typically shows initially bilateral basal infiltrates → diffuse involvement
- Dx : Serology, PCR for the virus, detection of viral antigen
- Rx : supportive within an ICU, including the use of ECMO
- ? person-to-person transmission occurs, and patients should be in respiratory isolation.
- IV ribavirin may be administered, although this has not been demonstrated to improve outcome
- Mortality 10-50%, with death usually occurring within several days of presentation.

# PNEUMONIA IN IMMUNOCOMPROMISED

Overall, there are six main types of immunosuppression:
1.  Iatrogenic (through steroidal and nonsteroidal agents);
2.  Neutropenia (usually through antineoplastic chemotherapy);
3.  Haematopoietic stem-cell transplantation (HSCT);
4.  Solid-organ transplantation;
5.  Uncontrolled HIV infection;
6.  Innate or acquired T- and B-cell deficiencies.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      The current thinking is that the universe is expanding, and that it began with a Big Bang. The Big Bang theory states that the universe began as a very hot, dense, and small point, and has been expanding and cooling ever since. The expansion of the universe is still ongoing, and is accelerating. The accelerating expansion of the universe is thought to be caused by a mysterious force called dark energy. Dark energy is thought to make up about 68% of the universe, and dark matter is thought to make up about 27%. The remaining 5% is made up of ordinary matter, which is what we are made of.

sectionTitle: The Big Bang theory is supported by a number of ob
content:
The Big Bang theory is supported by a number of observations, including:
*   The expansion of the universe
*   The cosmic microwave background radiation
*   The abundance of light elements
*   The large-scale structure of the universe

The expansion of the universe is observed by the redshift of light from distant galaxies. The cosmic microwave background radiation is a faint glow of light that fills the universe, and is thought to be the leftover radiation from the Big Bang. The abundance of light elements, such as hydrogen and helium, is consistent with the predictions of the Big Bang theory. The large-scale structure of the universe, such as the distribution of galaxies and clusters of galaxies, is also consistent with the predictions of the Big Bang theory.

The Big Bang theory is the most widely accepted theory for the origin and evolution of the universe. However, there are still some unanswered questions, such as:
*   What caused the Big Bang?
*   What is dark energy?
*   What is dark matter?

Scientists are continuing to study the universe in an effort to answer these questions.

Pt on Immunosuppressive Rx 4. 1° Immunodeficiency **CF:** Fever + dry cough + SOB $\Rightarrow$ Hypoxemia **CXR:** Initially CXR(N) $\longrightarrow$ Perihilar infiltrates $\qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \downarrow$ $\qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad$ BIL interstitial pattern $\qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad$ CT chest: BIL GGOs * Pneumatocels & PTx can happen Dr Bharath Katti Pulmonologist --- *Indirect marking & LDH↑* **Dx: BAL >> Routine sputum** → Visualise cyst → Wright Giemsa stain → Gomori methamine silver stain → Immunofluorescent stain (21 days) **BLOOD TEST: ELEVATED β-d-Glucan** (Fungal cell wall component) TMP-SMX *15-20 mg/kg (TMP component) daily (q6-8 hr)* **COTRIMOXAZOLE** **PNEUMOCYSTIS** **DOC: Rx: Cotrimoxazole** ← DOC for prophylaxis [Trimethoprim + Sulfamethoxazole] Septrin DS → TMP ⇒ 160mg ↓ Smx ⇒ 800mg **Alternate drugs:** 1. Trimethoprim + Dapsone 2. Clindamycin + Primaquine 3. Atovaquone 4. Pentamidine **- ROLE OF STEROIDS IN PNEUMOCYSTIS Pneumonia (PCP) ????** - During Rx In severe PCP (PaO2 <70 mmHg) → degradation of large amounts of *Pneumocystis* → severe inflammatory response. (A-a) gradient > 35mmHg - Steroid therapy can blunt this inflammatory response. Prednisone 40 mg BD FOR 5 days, then 40 mg OD for 5 days, then 20 mg OD for 11 days = Total: 21 days --- Prophylaxis CD4 < 200/ml - current Indian guidelines | Name of OI | Type of prophylaxis | What to start (preferred)* | Adult Dose | When to start | When to Stop | |---|---|---|---|---|---| | PCP | Primary | Co-trimoxazole | One double strength tablet (Sulfamethoxazole 800 mg + Trimethoprim 160 mg) | CD4 < 350 cells/cmm or WHO Clinical stage 3 or 4 condition | CD4 > 350cells/cmm (at least on two occasions, done 6 months apart) | | | Secondary | Co-trimoxazole | One double strength tablet (Sulfamethoxazole 800 mg + Trimethoprim 160 mg) | After successful treatment for PCP (21 days) | CD4 > 350cells/cmm (at least on two occasions, done 6 months apart) | **Handwritten Annotations:** * Next to "Primary" prophylaxis, under "Name of OI": Dosage: 5mg/kg of TMP/day OD * In "Adult Dose" column, next to "Primary" prophylaxis: NACO --- # Invasive Pulmonary Aspergillosis * Pneumonia in immunocompromised ≈ Neutropenia * Transbronchial angio invasion * PATHOLOGY: Hyphae within the alveoli penetrate to alveolar capillaries into endothelial cells Cell injury and inflammation → intravascular thrombosis, local hypoxia, and tissue damage → tissue infarction and coagulative necrosis * CF: SOB + hemoptysis ± fever?? * CT CHEST: * Active * * (less white [Blood] GGO) * (white consolidation) * CT HALO sign (fungus) * Recovery * * (Bodys immunity Clears) * Air crescent sign --- less white white CT HALO sign Air Crescent sign The CT halo sign : ground-glass opacities(less dense) is the result of alveolar hemorrhage around an fungal invasion related infarcted area of the lung (more dense) Dim Bright --- (AHS) pupillu Septate pneumocystis - B-D-glucan ## DIAGNOSIS & Rx Positive galactomannan in serum | BAL * **BIOPSY:** Septate hyphae with acute angle branching * **Others:** Fungal culture / PCR * **Doc:** Voriconazole 6mg/kg bd day 1 f/b 4mg/kg bd for 6-12 weeks (3m) * **Other options:** Isavuconazole, Posaconazole * **Liposomal amphotericin** used for IPA in patients refractory to or intolerant of azoles.

sectionTitle: Table 2. Diagnostic criteria for invasive aspergillosis
content: ### Table 2. Diagnostic criteria for invasive aspergillosis

# Mucormycosis $\rightarrow$ mucor $\rightarrow$ Rhizopus \* URT + LRT + CNS involvement * Riskfactors: MC : (DM) \* * Pathology: Similar to Aspergillus, mucormycosis is angioinvasive, resulting in thrombosis, infarction, and tissue necrosis, with risk for dissemination to other sites. \*t * Signs and symptoms: 1. # Imaging:
*   bronchopneumonia or lobar consolidation with cavitations
*   solitary, multiple or miliary nodules, and abscesses
*   Pleural effusion develops in up to one-third of cases
*   brain abscesses can develop in up to 40% of patients, CNS imaging should be considered in all patients with pulmonary nocardia
